"**Time After Time** " is the second single by American singer-songwriter
[Cyndi Lauper](/wiki/Cyndi_Lauper "Cyndi Lauper") from her debut studio album,
_[She's So Unusual](/wiki/She%27s_So_Unusual "She's So Unusual")_ (1983), with
[Rob Hyman](/wiki/Rob_Hyman "Rob Hyman") (co-writer and founding member of the
rock band [The Hooters](/wiki/The_Hooters "The Hooters")) contributing backing
vocals. The track was produced by [Rick Chertoff](/wiki/Rick_Chertoff "Rick
Chertoff") and released as a single on January 27, 1984. The song became
Lauper's first number 1 hit in the U.S. The song was written in the album's
final stages, after "Girls Just Wanna Have Fun", "She Bop" and "All Through
the Night" had been written. The writing began with the title, which Lauper
had seen in _[TV Guide](/wiki/TV_Guide "TV Guide")_ magazine, referring to the
science fiction film _[Time After Time](/wiki/Time_After_Time_\(1979_film\)
"Time After Time \(1979 film\)")_ (1979).[2]

"Time After Time" is composed of simple keyboard-synth chords, bright, jangly
guitars, clock-ticking percussion, and elastic bassline. Lyrically, it is a
love song of devotion. Music critics gave the song positive reviews, with many
commending the song for being a solid and memorable love song. The song has
been selected as one of the Best Love Songs of All Time by many media outlets,
including _[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone")_ ,
[Nerve](/wiki/Nerve_\(website\) "Nerve \(website\)"), [MTV](/wiki/MTV "MTV")
and many others.[3] "Time After Time" was also nominated for a [Grammy Award
for Song of the Year](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Song_of_the_Year "Grammy Award
for Song of the Year") at the [1985 edition](/wiki/Grammy_Awards_of_1985
"Grammy Awards of 1985").[4] The song was a success on the charts, becoming
her first number-one single on the US [_Billboard_](/wiki/Billboard_charts
"Billboard charts") [Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100")
chart on June 9, 1984, and remaining there for two weeks. The song reached
number three on the [UK Singles Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles
Chart") and number six on the [ARIA Singles Chart](/wiki/ARIA_Charts "ARIA
Charts").

The song is also known for its numerous covers by a wide range of artists,
including [Miles Davis](/wiki/Miles_Davis "Miles Davis"), who recorded an
instrumental version for his 1985 album _[You're Under
Arrest](/wiki/You%27re_Under_Arrest_\(Miles_Davis_album\) "You're Under Arrest
\(Miles Davis album\)")_, and [Eva Cassidy](/wiki/Eva_Cassidy "Eva Cassidy"),
whose cover of the song appears on her posthumous [album of the same
name](/wiki/Time_After_Time_\(Eva_Cassidy_album\) "Time After Time \(Eva
Cassidy album\)"). [R&B](/wiki/R%26B "R&B") singer [Lil Mo](/wiki/Lil_Mo "Lil
Mo") also covered the song for her 2001 debut album _[Based on a True
Story](/wiki/Based_on_a_True_Story_\(Lil%27_Mo_album\) "Based on a True Story
\(Lil' Mo album\)")_. An acoustic version was sung by Lauper with [Sarah
McLachlan](/wiki/Sarah_McLachlan "Sarah McLachlan") on her 2005 album _[The
Body Acoustic](/wiki/The_Body_Acoustic "The Body Acoustic")_.[5] Lauper has
performed the song live with [Patti LaBelle](/wiki/Patti_LaBelle "Patti
LaBelle") twice in 1985 and 2004 and with [Sarah
McLachlan](/wiki/Sarah_McLachlan "Sarah McLachlan") at the [American Music
Awards of 2005](/wiki/American_Music_Awards_of_2005 "American Music Awards of
2005"),[6] as well as with rapper [Lil' Kim](/wiki/Lil%27_Kim "Lil' Kim") in
2009.

## Background and
recording[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Time_After_Time_\(Cyndi_Lauper_song\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background and recording")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Rob_Hyman.jpg/150px-
Rob_Hyman.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rob_Hyman.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rob_Hyman.jpg "Enlarge")

[Rob Hyman](/wiki/Rob_Hyman "Rob Hyman") (_pictured_) co-wrote and sings
background vocals on the track.

While writing for her debut studio album, in the spring of 1983, [Cyndi
Lauper](/wiki/Cyndi_Lauper "Cyndi Lauper") was introduced to American musician
[Rob Hyman](/wiki/Rob_Hyman "Rob Hyman"), who was recommended by [Rick
Chertoff](/wiki/Rick_Chertoff "Rick Chertoff"), the album's producer. Lauper
had already recorded the majority of the album, including the songs "[Girls
Just Want to Have Fun](/wiki/Girls_Just_Want_to_Have_Fun "Girls Just Want to
Have Fun")", "[She Bop](/wiki/She_Bop "She Bop")" and "[All Through the
Night](/wiki/All_Through_the_Night_\(Cyndi_Lauper_song\) "All Through the
Night \(Cyndi Lauper song\)")", but Chertoff insisted that she and Hyman
needed to record just "one more song". Therefore, she and Hyman sat at a piano
and started working on "Time After Time".[7] The inspiration for the song came
after both songwriters were going through similar situations in their
respective relationships; he was coming out of a relationship, while she was
having difficulties with her boyfriend, David Wolff. One of the first lines
Rob wrote was "suitcase of memories", which according to Lauper, "struck her",
claiming it was a "wonderful line", while other lines came from Lauper's life.
The song's title was inspired after Lauper started writing for the song and
needed a fake title as a placeholder for the time being. Thus, Lauper was
looking in the _[TV Guide](/wiki/TV_Guide "TV Guide")_ and saw a lot of movie
titles, with the 1979 science fiction movie _[Time After
Time](/wiki/Time_After_Time_\(1979_film\) "Time After Time \(1979 film\)")_
being chosen. Although trying to remove the title later, Lauper claimed she
couldn't take it out without the song falling apart.[7]

Initially, Epic Records wanted "Time After Time" as the album's lead single.
However, Lauper felt that releasing a ballad first defines an artist in a
certain way, noting that she could have been known as a balladeer and that it
could have killed her career. Her manager Dave Wolff was convinced that "Girls
Just Wanna Have Fun" could be an anthem, and ultimately her label agreed and
released it as the lead single.[7] "Time After Time" eventually became the
album's second single,[8] being released on January 27, 1984.[9]

## Composition and
lyrics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Time_After_Time_\(Cyndi_Lauper_song\)&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Composition and lyrics")]

Written by [Cyndi Lauper](/wiki/Cyndi_Lauper "Cyndi Lauper") and [Rob
Hyman](/wiki/Rob_Hyman "Rob Hyman") and produced by [Rick
Chertoff](/wiki/Rick_Chertoff "Rick Chertoff"), "Time After Time" is built
over simple keyboard-synth chords, bright, jangly [guitars](/wiki/Guitar
"Guitar"), [clock ticking](/wiki/Clock_tick "Clock tick")
[percussion](/wiki/Percussion "Percussion"), and elastic
[bassline](/wiki/Bassline "Bassline").[10] Lyrically, the track is a love song
of devotion.[11] Pam Avoledo of _[Blogcritics](/wiki/Blogcritics
"Blogcritics")_ speculates that, "In 'Time After Time,' Lauper believes she is
a difficult person, unworthy of love. She runs away and shuts people out.
However, her devoted boyfriend who loves her unconditionally is willing to
help her through anything. The relationship is given depth. The couple’s
intimacy and history is apparent. They've been together for a long time. They
love and have seen each other through every tough part of their life."[12]

"Time After Time" is written in the key of [C major](/wiki/C_major "C major")
with a [tempo](/wiki/Tempo "Tempo") of 130 beats per minute[13] in [common
time](/wiki/Time_signature "Time signature"). Lauper's vocals span from G3 to
C5 in the song.[14]

## Critical
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Time_After_Time_\(Cyndi_Lauper_song\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Critical reception")]

The song received critical acclaim:

  * Sal Cinquemani of _[Slant Magazine](/wiki/Slant_Magazine "Slant Magazine")_ praised the track, calling it "the album's finest moment, if not Lauper's greatest moment period."[10]
  * Susan Glen of _[PopMatters](/wiki/PopMatters "PopMatters")_ also called it a standout track, naming it "gorgeous".[15]
  * Bryan Lee Madden of _[Sputnikmusic](/wiki/Sputnikmusic "Sputnikmusic")_ simply called it "a masterpiece" and "the best and most significant song she ever wrote or recorded."[16] Brenon Veevers of _Renowned for Sound_ labeled it "sentimental" and "gorgeous".[17]
  * Pam Avoledo of _[Blogcritics](/wiki/Blogcritics "Blogcritics")_ described the song as "a sure-fire classic".[12]
  * Scott Floman, music critic for _[Goldmine](/wiki/Goldmine_\(magazine\) "Goldmine \(magazine\)")_ magazine, described the song as "gorgeously heartfelt" and "one of the decade’s finest ballads".[18]
  * Chris Gerard of _[Metro Weekly](/wiki/Metro_Weekly "Metro Weekly")_ summarized the song as a "beautiful and bittersweet ballad."[19]

###
Accolades[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Time_After_Time_\(Cyndi_Lauper_song\)&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Accolades")]

"Time After Time" has entered many lists of "Best Love Songs of All Time",
"Best Ballads from the 80's" and others. Steve Peake of
_[About.com](/wiki/About.com "About.com")_ listed the song at number 6 on her
"Top Songs of the '80s", writing that the song "stands tall among the music of
the entire rock era as one of its all-time great timeless ballads," noting
that "it probably still functions impeccably as a properly emotionally
wrenching slow-dance favorite."[11] Bill Lamb, also from _About.com_ , placed
the song at number 21 on his "Top 100 Best Love Songs Of All Time" list.[20]
On _[Nerve](/wiki/Nerve_\(website\) "Nerve \(website\)")'_s list of "The 50
Greatest Love Songs of All Time", "Time After Time" was placed at number 5,
being called "Lauper's most enduring masterpiece hits at the very essence of
commitment," with the article pointing out that "she captures real romance in
the most simple and straightforward of lines: 'If you're lost, you can look
and you will find me, time after time'."[21] The song also entered the
[Rolling Stone](/wiki/Rolling_Stone "Rolling Stone") & [MTV](/wiki/MTV
"MTV")'s "100 Greatest Pop Songs" at number 66.[3] The song also entered
[VH1](/wiki/VH1 "VH1")'s "100 Best Songs of the Past 25 Years and "100
Greatest Songs of the 80s" lists, at numbers 22 and 19 respectively.[22][23]
The song was also present on [NME](/wiki/NME "NME")'s 100 Best Songs of the
1980s, being ranked at number 79. The website declared that "‘Time After Time’
was a change in tack for Lauper, whose musical persona had previously been
unstoppably light and frothy. ‘Time After Time’ was demoed quickly in time for
inclusion on her debut ‘She’s So Unusual’, and ended up being a key song for
both Lauper’s career and the decade itself."[24]

## Chart
performance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Time_After_Time_\(Cyndi_Lauper_song\)&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Chart performance")]

"Time After Time" became Lauper's first number-one single on the [Billboard
charts](/wiki/Billboard_charts "Billboard charts"), reaching the top of the
[_Billboard_ Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") chart in
June 1984.[25] It also reached the top of the [Adult
Contemporary](/wiki/Adult_Contemporary "Adult Contemporary")[26] and [Canadian
Singles Chart](/wiki/Canadian_Singles_Chart "Canadian Singles Chart").[27] In
the United Kingdom, "Time After Time" first peaked at number 54 on March 24,
1984, while peaking later at number 3, on June 16, 1984.[28] In New Zealand,
the song reached number 3,[29] in Austria it reached number 5,[30] in
Switzerland it reached number 7,[31] in France it peaked at number 9[9] and in
Sweden it reached a peak of number 10.[32]

## Music
video[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Time_After_Time_\(Cyndi_Lauper_song\)&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Music video")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Morristown%2C_NJ%2C_train_station_interior.jpg/200px-
Morristown%2C_NJ%2C_train_station_interior.jpg)](/wiki/File:Morristown,_NJ,_train_station_interior.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Morristown,_NJ,_train_station_interior.jpg "Enlarge")

Morristown, NJ, train station, seen at the end of the video.

The [video](/wiki/Music_video "Music video") for "Time After Time" was
directed by [Edd Griles](/wiki/Edd_Griles "Edd Griles"), and its storyline is
about a young woman leaving her lover behind when she becomes homesick and
worried about her mother. Lauper's mother, brother, and then-boyfriend, David
Wolff, appear in the video, and [Lou Albano](/wiki/Lou_Albano "Lou Albano"),
who played her father in the "[Girls Just Want to Have
Fun](/wiki/Girls_Just_Want_to_Have_Fun "Girls Just Want to Have Fun")" video,
can be seen as a cook. Portions of the video were filmed at the now-closed
Tom's Diner in [Roxbury Township, New
Jersey](/wiki/Roxbury_Township,_New_Jersey "Roxbury Township, New Jersey"),
the intersection of Route 46 and Route 10 and at the [Morristown train
station](/wiki/Morristown_\(NJT_station\) "Morristown \(NJT station\)").
Portions of the video were also shot in front of Betty's Department Store in
Wharton, NJ, which was a staple of the community in the 1970s. According to
Lauper, "It was important to me that we were natural and human in the video. I
wanted to convey somebody who walked her own path and did not always get along
with everyone and did not always marry the guy." The video opens with Lauper
watching the 1936 film _[The Garden of
Allah](/wiki/The_Garden_of_Allah_\(1936_film\) "The Garden of Allah \(1936
film\)")_ and the final scene, where she gets on the train and waves goodbye
to David, has Lauper crying for real.[33]

## Cover
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Time_After_Time_\(Cyndi_Lauper_song\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Cover versions")]

  * American R&B singer [INOJ](/wiki/INOJ "INOJ") recorded the song in 1998. Her version peaked at number six on [Billboard Hot 100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100") Charts in the U.S.[70] The music video of this version first aired on [BET](/wiki/BET "BET") and [The Box](/wiki/The_Box_\(U.S.\) "The Box \(U.S.\)").[71]
  * [Novaspace](/wiki/Novaspace "Novaspace"): The German [Eurodance](/wiki/Eurodance "Eurodance") project covered the song on their album _Novaspace_ (2002). It reached number 6 in Germany, number 7 in Austria and #15 in Australia.[72]
  * American alternative rock/pop punk band [Quietdrive](/wiki/Quietdrive "Quietdrive") covered the song for their debut album _[When All That's Left Is You](/wiki/When_All_That%27s_Left_Is_You "When All That's Left Is You")_ in 2006. The cover version was featured in the 2006 romantic comedy film _[John Tucker Must Die](/wiki/John_Tucker_Must_Die "John Tucker Must Die")_ starring [Jesse Metcalfe](/wiki/Jesse_Metcalfe "Jesse Metcalfe") and [Brittany Snow](/wiki/Brittany_Snow "Brittany Snow"). The cover is their only charting song, hitting number 25 on the American Top 40 Countdown.[73] The cover was certified gold by the [RIAA](/wiki/RIAA "RIAA").[74]
  * In April 2011, on the premiere of the American version of the reality competition television series _[The Voice](/wiki/The_Voice_\(U.S._TV_series\) "The Voice \(U.S. TV series\)")_ , [Javier Colon](/wiki/Javier_Colon "Javier Colon") performed an acoustic version of the song during the "blind audition" phase. The studio recording of his cover peaked at number 65 on the _Billboard_ Hot 100 Chart,[75] number 41 on the [Digital Songs](/wiki/Digital_Songs "Digital Songs") chart,[76] number 16 on the [R&B/Hip-Hop Digital Songs](/wiki/Hot_R%26B/Hip-Hop_Songs "Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs") chart,[77] and number 4 on the [Top Heatseekers](/wiki/Top_Heatseekers "Top Heatseekers") chart.[78]

## Other versions and
samples[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Time_After_Time_\(Cyndi_Lauper_song\)&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Other versions and samples")]

  * [Kids Incorporated](/wiki/Kids_Incorporated "Kids Incorporated") covered "Time After Time" in 1984 in the Season 1 episode "X Marks the Spot" and in 1987 in the Season 4 episode "You've Got the Wrong Date".
  * American Dance/Hi NRG artist [Paul Parker](/wiki/Paul_Parker_\(singer\) "Paul Parker \(singer\)") released a cover of "Time After Time" in 1985.
  * [Miles Davis](/wiki/Miles_Davis "Miles Davis") recorded the song on his 1985 album _[You're Under Arrest](/wiki/You%27re_Under_Arrest_\(Miles_Davis_album\) "You're Under Arrest \(Miles Davis album\)")_.[2]
  * [Tuck & Patti](/wiki/Tuck_%26_Patti "Tuck & Patti") recorded a version of the song on their first album _Tears of Joy_ in 1988.
  * New Zealand singer [Mark Williams](/wiki/Mark_Williams_\(singer\) "Mark Williams \(singer\)") and Australian actress/singer [Tara Morice](/wiki/Tara_Morice "Tara Morice") recorded the song as a duet for the soundtrack of the movie _[Strictly Ballroom](/wiki/Strictly_Ballroom "Strictly Ballroom")_ in 1992.
  * [Everything But The Girl](/wiki/Everything_But_The_Girl "Everything But The Girl") included a cover of the song on their acoustic album _[Acoustic (Everything but the Girl album)](/wiki/Acoustic_\(Everything_but_the_Girl_album\) "Acoustic \(Everything but the Girl album\)")_
  * [Eva Cassidy](/wiki/Eva_Cassidy "Eva Cassidy")'s version of the song was published on her album _[Time After Time](/wiki/Time_After_Time_\(Eva_Cassidy_album\) "Time After Time \(Eva Cassidy album\)")_ in 2000, four years after her death in 1996.
  * American R&B Duo [Changing Faces](/wiki/Changing_Faces_\(group\) "Changing Faces \(group\)") recorded the song as an album track for their 1997 Album "All Day, All Night". Their version was not released as a single.
  * American girl group [Blaque](/wiki/Blaque "Blaque") covered "Time After Time" on their debut album _[Blaque](/wiki/Blaque_\(album\) "Blaque \(album\)")_ in 1999.
  * American [R&B](/wiki/R%26B "R&B") singer [Lil Mo](/wiki/Lil_Mo "Lil Mo") recorded the song for her 2001 debut album _[Based on a True Story](/wiki/Based_on_a_True_Story_\(Lil%27_Mo_album\) "Based on a True Story \(Lil' Mo album\)")_.
  * English garage act [Distant Soundz](/wiki/Distant_Soundz "Distant Soundz") recorded a version of the song in 2002 featuring Robbie Beaumont, which reached number 20 in the UK charts.
  * [Willie Nelson](/wiki/Willie_Nelson "Willie Nelson") covered the song on his album _[The Great Divide](/wiki/The_Great_Divide_\(Willie_Nelson_album\) "The Great Divide \(Willie Nelson album\)")_ in 2002.
  * French singer [Nolwenn Leroy](/wiki/Nolwenn_Leroy "Nolwenn Leroy") covered the song for her 2007 live album _Histoires Naturelles Tour_.[97]
  * Irish singer/songwriter [Ronan Keating](/wiki/Ronan_Keating "Ronan Keating") rendered the song in 2008. The rendition is the first single released from Keating's fifth solo album, _[Songs for My Mother](/wiki/Songs_for_My_Mother "Songs for My Mother")_ (2009). The single was released on February 8, 2009, and became Keating's first single to be released in three years. The song was produced by Keating himself. The song peaked at number 88 on the [UK Singles Chart](/wiki/UK_Singles_Chart "UK Singles Chart").[98]
  * Actress and singer, [Anna Kendrick](/wiki/Anna_Kendrick "Anna Kendrick") performed a cover of the song on [the soundtrack](/wiki/Up_in_the_Air_\(soundtrack\) "Up in the Air \(soundtrack\)") to the film _[Up in the Air](/wiki/Up_in_the_Air_\(2009_film\) "Up in the Air \(2009 film\)")_ , in which she starred.
  * In June 2016, Ben Weighill covered the song in an advert for bed company Dreams.[99]
  * The Lovelocks, a Canadian CCMA® nominated female roots-country duo consisting of Ali Raney and Zoe Neuman released their cover of "Time After Time" in July, 2016 [100][101]
  * [U96](/wiki/U96 "U96"): "[Heaven](/wiki/Heaven_\(U96_song\) "Heaven \(U96 song\)")" (1996).[102] It reached #2 in Austria, #7 in Finland, #4 in Germany, #15 in the Netherlands, #5 in Norway, #5 in Sweden and #16 in Switzerland.
  * In 2006, [Alison Pill](/wiki/Alison_Pill "Alison Pill") covered this song in the seventh episode of the short lived NBC series [The Book of Daniel (TV series)](/wiki/The_Book_of_Daniel_\(TV_series\) "The Book of Daniel \(TV series\)").
  * In 2008, American actress/singer [Ashley Tisdale](/wiki/Ashley_Tisdale "Ashley Tisdale") covered this song as a promotion for Degree Girl antiperspirant.
  * Canadian pop singer [Carly Rae Jepsen](/wiki/Carly_Rae_Jepsen "Carly Rae Jepsen") performed a cover of the song at Lauper's induction into the [Songwriters Hall of Fame](/wiki/Songwriters_Hall_of_Fame "Songwriters Hall of Fame") in 2015.[103][104]
  * Sung by [Chrissy Metz](/wiki/Chrissy_Metz "Chrissy Metz") on the _[This Is Us](/wiki/This_Is_Us_\(TV_series\) "This Is Us \(TV series\)")_ episode "Kyle."
  * American singer-songwriter and pianist [Merry Ellen Kirk](/w/index.php?title=Merry_Ellen_Kirk&action=edit&redlink=1 "Merry Ellen Kirk \(page does not exist\)") covered this song on her 2015 album, We are the Dreamers.
  * [Iron & Wine](/wiki/Iron_%26_Wine "Iron & Wine") recorded a version of the song for a McDonald's commercial in 2016.
  * American singer-songwriter [Mariah Carey](/wiki/Mariah_Carey "Mariah Carey") sampled the song in her track "Inseparable", included on her album [Memoirs of an Imperfect Angel](/wiki/Memoirs_of_an_Imperfect_Angel "Memoirs of an Imperfect Angel") in 2009.
